title: Tudor Period Words
description: Explore the language of the Tudor dynasty, from Henry VII to Elizabeth I (1485-1603)

questions.question: In Tudor England, what was a 'privy council'?
options: A group of advisors chosen by the monarch to help govern

questions.question: What was 'the Reformation' in Tudor vocabulary?
options: The religious movement that led to the break with the Catholic Church

questions.question: In Tudor times, what was a 'codpiece'?
options: A pouch attached to the front of men's breeches
A piece of cod liver oil

questions.question: What was a 'yeoman' in Tudor England?
options: A man of modest rank who owned and farmed his own land

questions.question: In Tudor vocabulary, what was a 'great hall'?
options: The main room of a manor house used for dining and gatherings

questions.question: What did 'treason' specifically mean under Tudor law?
options: Betrayal of the sovereign, punishable by death

questions.question: In Tudor England, what was 'simony'?
options: The buying or selling of religious privileges or offices

questions.question: What was a 'wimple' in Tudor fashion?
options: A cloth headdress covering the head, chin, and neck

questions.question: In Tudor times, what was 'the Tower' short for?
options: The Tower of London, used as a royal prison and fortress

questions.question: What was a 'recusant' in Tudor England?
options: A person who refused to attend Church of England services

questions.question: In Tudor vocabulary, what was a 'knave'?
options: A dishonest or unprincipled person, or a male servant

questions.question: What was 'physick' in the Tudor era?
options: Medicine or the art of healing

questions.question: In Tudor England, what was 'the sweating sickness'?
options: A mysterious and deadly epidemic disease that struck rapidly

questions.question: What was a 'jointure' in Tudor legal terms?
options: Property settled on a wife for her support after her husband's death

questions.question: In Tudor times, what was a 'progress'?
options: A royal tour through the countryside, staying at noble households
